conversation.content: [surprised] So you're the one who called in the emergency outage report from Maple Street—I didn't realize you still lived in Mom's old house after all these years.
Well, someone had to keep it from falling apart completely, unlike certain people who disappeared the moment things got difficult with her care. [bitter laugh]
The transformer feeding your block is showing serious degradation, probably been failing slowly for months now, which explains the flickering you mentioned. [pause]
[dismissive] Always hiding behind the technical stuff, aren't you? Even now you can't just have a normal conversation about why you haven't returned a single call in three years.
[defensive] Look, I'm here to fix your power situation, not rehash ancient history about who did or didn't show up when Mom needed dialysis appointments every other day.
Ancient history? She died eighteen months ago, Marcus, and you couldn't even make it to the funeral because of some supposed emergency at the substation.
[quietly] That emergency was real—half the hospital district lost power that morning, including the cardiac wing where they were doing open-heart surgeries.
Sure, and I suppose every holiday, birthday, and Sunday dinner for the past decade had similar life-or-death situations preventing you from showing up. [exhales]
You think I wanted to be the one who left? You think it was easy watching you become her perfect caregiver while I became the family disappointment? [voice breaking]
[softer] Perfect caregiver? I was drowning, Marcus, absolutely drowning, and every time I called begging for just a weekend off, you had another excuse.
I sent money every month, made sure the mortgage stayed current, paid for the nurse when insurance wouldn't cover it—that had to count for something.
[tired] Money isn't the same as being there to hold her hand when she was scared, or listening to her tell the same stories about Dad for the hundredth time. [sighs]
[barely audible] I know.
She kept asking for you near the end, kept thinking you were just running late from work, and I had to keep making excuses about traffic on the interstate.
[struggling] The thing is, I knew if I came back, if I saw her like that, I'd never be able to leave again, and I was terrified of that.
[weary] And here we are, both stuck in this house anyway—you fixing the power, me living with her ghost in every corner of every room. [hollow laugh]
[resigned] Yeah, I guess so.
The transformer isn't the only thing that's been slowly failing around here, but at least that's something you actually know how to fix.
[firmly] I'll need to schedule a full replacement next week, and I'll handle the paperwork myself to expedite it—it's the least I can do at this point.
The least you can do.

scenario: A substation technician is called to investigate a power outage at their estranged sibling's neighborhood, discovering they're the one who made the emergency call.
